I've stumbled upon a unique bug (or perhaps feature, from the carriers' perspective) relating to what appears to be keyword blacklisting in SMS messages: From what I can tell in my limited testing, outbound text messages from some devices on the T-Mobile network are being silently blocked if they contain the phrase "verification code" anywhere in their content, but  only when they are sent to certain combinations of carriers and devices. I'm posting here to see if users with more knowledge surrounding mobile networks and platforms can provide any insight, or chime in to say if this is known/expected behavior. I apologize for the wall of text that follows (you can just look at the tables and tl;dr for the gist of the matter), but I'm aiming to be as descriptive as possible to help others reproduce the issue.
 Brief background: I'm the resident techie for friends and family, and I frequently help troubleshoot issues with various online services. When doing so, I'll occasionally need to log into their accounts directly from my computer, and for the accounts that have an OTP-based 2FA that's sent out via SMS, I just ask them to forward the text message they receive containing the verification code to my phone so I can complete the authentication process. This past week, I ran into two separate instances where I was helping someone with an account secured with SMS 2FA and there was significant difficulty communicating the requisite code, to the point that it piqued my interest and started me down the path of troubleshooting.
 In the first instance, a friend said they had forwarded me the code message from the service, but nothing appeared on my end. I had the service send a new OTP code to them, and they once again said they had forwarded it to me , but I still didn't see anything on my end. We tried the same loop of the system re-sending and them forwarding once more, with the same result. At this point, I chalked it up to some generic SMS issues and had them just call me with the code so I could complete the login process and move forward. The only thing that struck me as odd was that their text messages about  sending me the codes were coming through just fine, even though the messages with the codes were apparently failing to arrive. They sent me a screenshot of their side of the conversation, and it did indeed show the messages successfully going out on their end, but I still chalked it up to some sort of temporary glitch and didn't devote further thought to it at the time.
 Yesterday, however, I had an inversion of the same behavior occur: When I sent an SMS to a family member asking them to pass on their verification code to me, they didn't respond at all, and when I asked them about it, they said they never received my text. Recalling what had happened earlier in the week, I looked back at the screenshots of the texts and considered what commonalities there were between the two conversations. The messages that the friend had attempted to forward and those I sent requesting the code were all relatively short and did not contain any unique characters so far as I could tell, so I couldn't imagine it being an issue with SMS length cap triggering MMS conversion or anything else that I had historically seen drive transmission issues. The sole consistent factor I could identify among the messages was that they all contained the exact phrase "verification code" somewhere within them.
 I didn't think it was likely that specific words would have an impact on text delivery, but since I had no other hypotheses, I decided it was worth at least performing a quick test. I sent the same family member a message with the simple phrase  This is a verification code test. and asked them to tell me if it arrived. They received my text asking them to respond, but the original message containing the words "verification code" never arrived. After waiting a couple of minutes to ensure it wasn't just a delay, I tried sending a generic text with the phrase  Test message., which arrived immediately. I tried the original phrase twice more, with it failing to arrive on the opposite end both times. I then had the other party try sending the original phrase back to me, and the message arrived immediately, so the issue didn't appear to be bi-directional. Looking back at the screenshots of the conversation from earlier in the week, I saw that my message to the friend containing the words "verification code" arrived successfully, so the issue similarly appears unidirectional in that instance, although on the other end of the conversation.
 Having established the basic behavior, my next instinct was to test permutations to see if I could determine the scope/shape of the blockage. I sent a series of similar messages, with the following results:
    The pattern of successes and failures leads me to believe that whatever is causing the issue is performing a regex match along the lines of:  /v[^a-z\d]*e[^a-z\d]*r[^a-z\d]*i[^a-z\d]*f[^a-z\d]*i[^a-z\d]*c[^a-z\d]*a[^a-z\d]*t[^a-z\d]*i[^a-z\d]*o[^a-z\d]*n[^a-z\d]*[^a-z\d]*c[^a-z\d]*o[^a-z\d]*d[^a-z\d]*e/gi
 Essentially, it's blocking the specific phrase "verification code" with any permutation of non-alphanumeric characters intermingled.
  Since my phone is a Pixel 3a XL on the T-Mobile network, and the family member I was communicating with for these tests has an iPhone on Verizon, my next steps were to attempt to determine whether the issue was correlated with a specific device, platform/OS, carrier, or combination of the above. I contacted the few people I knew who wouldn't mind taking time out of a Friday evening to troubleshoot an odd mobile network glitch and asked them to perform a basic test, attempting to send the phrase "This is a verification code test." in both directions. I quickly ruled out the specific device model being a factor, which left the following based on carrier/OS combinations:
    "S" represents a successful transmission of the phrase "This is a verification code test." via text message.
 "x" represents the message failing to arrive on the recipient's end, even if it shows success on sender's end.
  Most of the table is obviously incomplete, but I will try to back-fill it as I gather further results or receive data from other users here. Based on the limited data set I was able to compile on short notice, my first interpretation was that it was a block between the T-Mobile and Verizon networks, because the failures appeared to occur only in the direction of T-Mobile to Verizon, agnostic of the device platform/OS. However, when I hit the outlier of a T-Mobile iPhone failing to send to T-Mobile Android, that threw a wrench in my network hypothesis. I'm not comfortable making a final judgment with only a single sample (albeit repeatable) in that pairing, so I'd like to get at least one other person with a T-Mobile iPhone that can verify the unidirectional failure of transmission to T-Mobile Android.  EDIT: Another user has run the same tests of T-Mobile iPhone to T-Mobile Android successfully, so I'm inclined to discount the pairing that's failing as a fluke, which would turn the focus back solely to the directional communications from T-Mobile to Verizon.
 The only guess I'm able to venture about this behavior is that it's the result of a fraud protection mechanism (attempting to protect users from SMS scams) that is suffering from an over-zealous ruleset, but I'm stumped as to why it would only affect certain combinations of devices and networks if that is the case.
 If anyone has friends/family/colleagues with combinations of devices for which I haven't been able to procure data (or for which I lack multiple samples), and you don't mind taking a couple minutes out of your day to run a some quick tests, please post your results in the comments and I'll try to keep the table updated.
  tl;dr: It appears that SMS messages containing the phrase "verification code" (and any permutations with non-alphanumeric separators) are being silently blocked when transmitting from T-Mobile to certain combinations of networks and devices (with all of Verizon failing to receive being the most conspicuous example). I'm looking to gather more data from anyone who can provide it, or to get feedback from an expert on whether this is known, expected behavior.
  EDIT: With further testing (report from  u/DJB719), it appears that the one sample of failure from T-Mobile iPhone to T-Mobile Android may be a fluke, meaning the only reproducible errors are from T-Mobile to Verizon. That suggests that this issue could be an error on Verizon's end performing inbound message filtering from the T-Mobile network. If further results point in that direction, it may be worth having one of the Verizon subscribers call to speak with their tech support, as well.
